# Getting Started

This app is very easy to run on any machine or host.

# Installation

All you need to run the project, is Docker.

# Sail

Recommended way to run the project is using Sail.

./vendor/bin/sail up -d --build

# Docker

If you can't/don't want to run the app using Sail, you can use plain Docker.

docker-compose up -d --build

# Configuration

For optimal configuration, please check Laravel Configuration docs.

# Broker

For dynamic configuration, project uses Laravel Service Container. 

class BrokerServiceProvider extends ServiceProvider
{
    public function register(): void
    {
        $this->app->singleton(BrokerContract::class, BrokerService::class);

        $this->app->when(BrokerService::class)
            ->needs(BrokerClientContract::class)
            ->give(static fn () => new BrokerClientService(config('broker.uri'), config('broker.user_id'), config('broker.password')));
    }
}

Implementations are situated in app/Modules/Trader/Providers folder.

Default broker is xStation, which works out of the box.

# Directory Structure

The Laravel Skeleton is kept as provided out of the box. Below, the custom folders and their purposes are specified.

Prefixed with App/Modules.

Trader/Collections

Manages and manipulates data chunks within Laravel applications.

Trader/Contracts

Defines interfaces resolved within service providers.

Trader/Facades

Offers a static interface to service container classes.

Trader/Indicators

Implements indicators like RSI, EMA, and SMA.

Trader/Interfaces

Defines interfaces used across the application.

Trader/Payloads

Defines request payloads sent via WebSocket.

Trader/Providers

Custom Laravel service providers.

Trader/Responses

Defines response objects from WebSocket clients.

Trader/Services

Concrete classes for service container binding and features.
